attributes.description: The virtuous and heroic prince of the Ikshváku line, described as an embodiment of justice and the darling sea of deeds.
The 'First of Bards' and author of the Rámáyan; a holy hermit and saint who receives the story from Nárad.
A divine saint and son of Brahmá, known as the eloquent messenger of the Gods and inventor of the víGá.
The preserving power of the Indian Trinity, who penetrates all things and has been incarnate nine times.
The wife of Ráma, daughter of Janak's royal lineage, and a 'miracle of loveliness' who follows her husband into exile.
The giant king of Lanká who abducts Sítá and is eventually slain by Ráma.
The son of the Wind-God and counselor to Sugríva who becomes a devoted ally to Ráma.
The ancestral capital where Ráma eventually returns to reign over his father's kingdom.
The island fortress ruled by RávaG, located across the deep sea.
The sacred epic poem that tells the deeds of Ráma, intended to free the world from sin.
Also known as Krita Yuga; a period of truth and perfection that returned during Ráma's reign.
The King and father of Ráma, Bharat, and LakshmaG, who dies pining for his exiled son.
The Vánar chief who forms an alliance with Ráma to recover his kingdom from Báli and find Sítá.

attributes.context: Válmíki is the parent mount and creator of the poem.
Nárad describes Ráma's virtues and history to Válmíki.
Ráma is described as the peer of VishGu's power and might, implying divinity.
Sítá is Ráma's darling wife who shares his exile.
Ráma returns to Ayodhyá to reign as king.
RávaG holds his royal sway in the town of Lanká.
Hanumán wins Ráma's steadfast friendship and serves as his envoy.
RávaG abducts Sítá from the hermitage using magic art.
Sugríva and Ráma swear alliance before the sacred flame.
Bharat is the brother who refuses the throne and rules as a regent via Ráma's sandals.
